body_text.text: has highlighted the fragility of psychological resilience, attention must be paid to the 40 psychological state of healthcare workers (HCW) during epidemics . 41 Although studies have documented the mental health status and related risk 42 factors that impacted the psychological stress and morbidities of HCW in previous 43 disease pandemics (Chong et al., 2004) , there are marked differences to the current 44 situation. Therefore, the psychological characteristics of HCW during the COVID-19 45 epidemic remains unknown. 46 If a physician has been in a state of anxiety for a long time, this will not only 47 adversely affect their physical health, but will also result in a lack of work efficiency 48 (Bargellini et al., 2000) . HCW are the main force for medical rescue, meaning an This study was a multi-center cross-sectional survey investigation. The 62 questionnaires were issued on January 28, 2020, one month after the start of 63 COVID-19 epidemic, at the peak of the epidemic period. The survey was in the form 64 of electronic questionnaires and was distributed to medical personnel in multiple 65 centers across the country via social media (WeChat, Tencent). The template of the 66 electronic questionnaire was provided by the application "Questionnaire Star" that 67 collected valid questionnaire results and summarized the information into an excel 68 table by category for subsequent statistical analysis.

Design and measures of survey 70 The questionnaire consists of three parts. The first part was concerned with 71 demographics and exposure factors, such as region, gender, education, specialty, 72 working experience, marital status, whether participants have children, whether they 73 live alone, their working position during the event, contact history and access to 74 protective equipment.

The second part was the PSS-14, which was used to evaluate the stress of 76 medical personnel following the outbreak. The scale contains 14 items, each of which 77 has a score ranging from 0 (absolutely no) to 4 (always yes). The higher the score, the 78 greater the HCW'S stress.

The third part was the HAD scale, which was used to evaluate anxiety and 80 depression. There were 14 questions, seven to detect anxiety levels and seven to 81 detect depression levels. Each question has a score of 0-3, 4-7 (asymptomatic), 8-10 82 (suspicious), and 11-21 (positive). A score greater than or equal to eight indicates 83 symptoms of depression or anxiety. To assess independent risk factors that result in anxiety and depression, we 93 defined 12 risk factors as independent variables and, anxiety and depression as 94 dependent variables. Effective factors were initially screened using a single factor 95 logistic regression with a p-value less than 0.1, and which were then put into multiple 96 factor logistic regression analysis. In this step, risks with p-value of less than 0.05 97 were considered independent risk factors that lead to anxiety and depression.
Characteristics of respondents 100 We collected a total of 958 anonymous and effective questionnaires across 26 28.9% had 6-10 years and 30.8% had less than five years (Table 1) .

Exposure factors were also listed in the survey ( years of work experience (less than 5 years, 6-10 years and more than 11 years) 129 (p=0.048) affected HCW stress levels (Table1). Given that contact history was an 163 independent risk factor for both anxiety and depression, we determined the correlation 164 between titles and contact history and found that the two factors were significantly 165 correlated (χ2=0.004) (Table 5) . However, at the 34 beginning of 2020, the outbreak and fast spread of the Severe Acute Respiratory 35 Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) disrupted all festival plans. In Wuhan City, 36 China, 11 million people were placed on lockdown to stop the further spread of 37 Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). In addition to changes in the pace of life, 38 unfamiliarity and uncontrollability enhanced people's stress. Given that this outbreak 39

FIGREF1.text: 49 evaluation of their psychological status to improve interventions, prevent 50 posttraumatic stress (PTS) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and enhance 51 their mental health is urgently needed. Thus, assessing mental health for HCW during 52 the COVID-19 epidemic is an inevitable precondition for coping with stress and 53 important measures for fighting disease.

FIGREF2.text: In the present study, we used the perceived stress scale-14 (PSS-14) and the55 hospital anxiety / depression scale (HAD) to evaluate the psychological stress, anxiety 56 and depression levels of HCW in multiple hospitals in China during COVID-19 the 57 epidemic. Risk factors for anxiety and depression were determined and interpreted to 58 provide further psychological interventions for this group of people.

FIGREF5.text: psychological illnesses such as anxiety and depression(Gong et al., 2014). We found 200 that more than half (54.2%) of the respondents developed anxiety, which is a much201 higher number than physicians in China (25.6-35.3%) (Ahmed et al., 2009; Gong et 202 al., 2014; Zhou et al., 2016) and other countries (2.2-24%) under typical conditions 203 (Ahmed et al., 2009). The anxiety levels of respondents were also higher than those of 204 medical residents (20%-30%) (Buddeberg-Fischer et al., 2009) and physicians in 205 oncology department (19%) (Paiva et al., 2018) who were assumed to be under 206 greater pressure than physicians in other departments. Additionally, 58% of HCW in 207 our study had symptoms of depression, which is higher than those of oncologists 208 (12%) (Paiva et al., 2018). 209 These data suggests an urgent need for psychological intervention for HCW, as 210 mental health is crucial not only for their own well-being, but also for their work 211 efficacy, which contributes to the quality of medical services and patient safety, and 212 may, in turn, affect psychological health of HCW (Ruotsalainen et al., 2014).

FIGREF6.text: anxiety and depression for the various degrees of protection. More importantly,218   protective measures were the independent risk factor for the development of anxiety219    and depression, which is in line with one study about SARS, in which it was found 220 the sufficient protection was a positive factor for mental health of HCW(Kaysen et   221   al., 2003). However, the sudden occurrence of the COVID-19 outbreak, which was222 both fast and widespread, the particular timing (coinciding with the Spring Festival) 223 and traffic control-led to a shortage of masks, goggles, face shields and protective 224 clothing. Under such conditions, some HCW used masks repeatedly and did not drink 225 water or go to the bathroom to prolong the life of their protective equipment, which 226 might reduce its effectiveness and increase the risk of infection. We suggest that these 227 physical and psychological responses induced symptoms of anxiety and depression. 228 Contact history was another important independent risk factor for both anxiety 229 and depression. However, the conclusion that contact history affects psychological 230 health is controversial. Authors of one study about SARS announced that contact with 231 an infected patient was not an adverse factor for psychological health (Maunder et al., 232 2006). In contrast, authors of another study indicated that HCW who had more 233 possible exposure to SARS were 2-3 times more likely to have high PTS levels than 234 those without exposure (Kaysen et al., 2003; Wu et al., 2009). In our study, when 235 compared to those who had had no contact, HCW who had contact with diagnosed 236 patients were approximately twice as likely to develop anxiety and depression. This is 237 because contact with infected and suspected patients will induce fear and uncertainty 238 for the virus, as there is no effective medication for treating COVID-19 pneumonia, 239 and the prognosis is inclusive. Additionally, the incubation time of COVID-19 240 pneumonia is longer than SARS, meaning the sustained and cumulative stress over 241 time turns into anxiety.242

In addition to 246 these previous findings, we firstly unveil that job titles affect stress as a result of 247 contact history(Table 5 andsupplementary figure 3). The senior and junior titles were 248 found to have significant differences in stress (Supplementary Figure 2), which could 249 be explained by the observation that juniors have more contact with infected patients 250 and specimens than senior HCW (Supplementary Figure 3). TABREF4.text: Supplementary figure 3). Epidemiological studies have documented during disease epidemics, HCW at 170 the forefront of the fight against illness are prone to stress responses (Mata et al., 2015). Such responses lead to changes in perception and development of 172 psychological morbidity such as anxiety, depression, PTS, and PTSD (Kaysen et al., 2003). Studies pointed out that SARS and the Middle East respiratory syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) caused high rates of psychological morbidity for HCW in 175 hospitals. Even one to three years after SARS, fear, chronic stress and depression 176 remained for HCW(Nickell et al., 2004). However, the prevalence of the psychological impacts of COVID-19 on HCW has not been reported. In the current about stress events, physical and psychological health and stress control(Cohen et al., 1983;Mimura and Griffiths, 2004). In one study PSS was used to examine the stress 186 of Chinese people under typical conditions. It was found that a score of 25 for females levels of HCW were higher than the general public in China during the COVID-19 epidemic, where 8.1% reported moderate to severe stress levels(Wang et al., 2020).
